text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with green tea mochi ice cream
that's right well it is a lot of fun to
do recipes that you're really confident
in and you know we're gonna come out
well every once awhile i think it's
critical to try recipe you're not good
at and you have no idea how to do and
for me this green tea mochi ice cream is
exactly that kind of recipe but anyway
I've had it at restaurants a few times
have been fascinated by its texture and
taste so I decided to give it a whirl
and this was my experience so we're
gonna get started by prepping the ice
cream and to do that I'm gonna use this
ice cream ball mold which looks just
like an egg carton in fact if you don't
have an ice cream ball mold you could
just go ahead and use an old egg carton
it will work perfectly and that's been
lined with plastic wrap and I'm gonna go
ahead and scoop in some vanilla ice
cream and the reason for this step is we
need to freeze these ice cream balls
really firm and solid so that we can
wrap them with our green tea mochi later
and they won't melt while we're doing it
so we're gonna scoop that ice cream out
we're gonna wrap that up and we're gonna
pop it in the freezer for a couple hours
until very very firm okay and once
that's been done we can move on to the
mochi dough is it called the dough I
don't even know if it's called the dough
but we're moving on to the mochi and the
main ingredient for that is something
called glutinous rice or I've seen it
called sweet rice flour and by the way
if you are living a glutinous free
lifestyle don't worry there's no gluten
in glutinous rice so we're gonna toss
some of that in a bowl and to that I'm
gonna add a tiny pinch of salt I'm not
sure if that's traditional but it just
felt right for me and then we're going
to pour in some water and give that a
stir and once that's all stirred
together we're going to add some sugar
now like I said at the beginning I have
absolutely no idea what I'm doing here I
only glanced at a couple recipes and
just decided to wing it but one thing I
saw said to put the sugar in after you
mix this together and why I don't know
I'm hoping some of you can tell me but
anyway I mix that up and then I added
some sugar
I continued mixing until it was
completely smooth and probably a whisk
would work better here but I went wooden
spoon it seemed a little more Japanese
to me and I guess that would be your
basic mochi mixture but since I want to
do a green tea mochi I'm going to add a
little spoon of green tea powder and
we'll stir that in and take a real good
look at that color because this is as
beautiful as it gets that color kind of
faded into more of a drab green as
you'll see but anyway we're going to mix
that in and at that point we are ready
to cook this and we are going to use the
ancient Japanese art of microwaving so
we're going to
I am plastic and pop it into our
microwave oven and we're going to cook
this for about three or four minutes and
halfway through we're going to want to
take it out and give it a stir so i
nuked mine for two minutes and when I
pulled it out it looked pretty scary and
it looked like it was one solid unstable
blob but once I got in there with a
wooden spoon it did stir and reminded me
of a very thick sticky roux so we're
gonna give that a mix and then we'll
rewrap that and put it back in the
microwave for a couple minutes although
we just got a new big giant powerful
microwave and I was a little afraid of
overcooking this so I just gave it
another minute and a half and when I
pulled it out and unwrapped it it was
pretty blurry but that was just me not
knowing how to focus so there we go and
we'll give that one more stir and I
guess that's cooked like I said I've
never made this before so I really
didn't have any idea but it seemed okay
at that point I'm going to transfer it
onto the work surface to roll out so I
went ahead and dusted liberally with
some more rice flour at that point we'll
go ahead and transfer our very sticky
and still very hot mochi onto that
surface and try to flatten this out and
by the way I'm using rice flour here so
it doesn't stick but most of the recipes
I saw use corn starch or potato starch
so hopefully someone can tell me why
that and not just more rice flour
there's got to be a reason I'm sure this
is wrong to use the rice flour but I
don't know why and you can see we're
also putting a generous amount on top so
our hand doesn't stick but anyway we're
going to press that flat and then switch
to a rolling pin and try to roll it to
about I don't know eighth of an inch
thick something like that and by the way
this is only really doable
while this is still warm so be careful
don't burn yourself it's very hot when
it comes out of the microwave but you do
want to work with the stuff while it's
still pretty warm but anyway once we've
rolled that out thin I'm going to take
my pizza cutter and slice this into
eight squares or more accurately eight
pieces and I'm pretty sure you know
what's coming next so we're going to
take our now completely frozen solid ice
cream balls and wrap it in these sheets
of green tea mochi and I did read you
don't want a lot of excess mochi like
bunched up underneath so once I wrapped
it it was clear I had too much so I took
my scissors I snipped a little off and
kind of squeezed that bottom together
and then what I did is I took little
pieces of plastic and wrapped them back
up gave it kind of a little twist and
I'm just going to put that right back in
our carton seam side down and once those
have been completed we'll simply freeze
in the same container so a pretty
efficient system and once those are all
done
all we need to do is freeze those for a
couple hours and we're ready to serve at
this point I was pretty optimistic I
mean for a first attempt they actually
looked like mochi wrapped ice cream so I
unwrapped one and especially when they
first come out of the freezer they have
this kind of permafrost on the top and
even if you rub it off it actually
Frost's back over it's kind of cool
so I unwrapped a few and it was time for
the first official taste test which I
did bon bon style so you can actually
eat these by picking them up like this
so I bit in with high hopes and I was
actually very happy the mochi came out
nice and thin it was just barely sweet
it had a beautiful chewy texture and
that little bit of bitterness from the
green tea really really works well with
the ice cream and of course if you don't
wanna get your hands dirty you can use a
spoon for these that's generally how you
get him into restaurants and then it was
time for taste test number two because I
wanted something a little prettier for
the pictures so I used this fancy little
cocktail glass which did look nice
except the curve of the spoon did not
match the curve at the bottom of the
glass and this quickly became one of the
biggest challenges of my culinary career
I just could not liberate that bite from
the cup but eventually after a
tremendous struggle I did except then I
thought to myself they should be able to
see the exposed surface so I tried to
turn that around and the peas got stuck
again
it really was a nightmare so little
heads up if you serve these in cups make
sure your curves match but anyway me and
my questionable spoon work aside it
really is a delicious frozen treat in
fact I was so happy I decided to break
out the solar-powered fist-pumping cat
to put next to this final shot and
actually thought it was a Japanese
solar-powered fist-pumping cat but I've
been informed those are actually Chinese
characters which I believe roughly
translates to while these Americans will
literally buy anything but regardless I
assume you're all pumping your fists in
unison right now as I say I really hope
you give this a try and tell me what I
did wrong and how I can improve this all
right so head over to food wishes comm
for all the ingredient amounts and more
info as usual and as always enjoy
you
